page.title: 09Wellhouse Hospital
page.content: The building dates back to 1834, when it was a workhouse, set up by the Guardians of the Poor. Many believe that Charles Dickens wrote Oliver Twist as an example of life in this Workhouse in 1835. In 1895 a sixty-bed infirmary was added. It was now called "Wellhouse Home". In 1913 six new wards were added and it became the "Wellhouse Hospital" Between 1914 and 1918 (during the Great War), the building was used as a military hospital. In 1920 it returned to civilian use once again. Several temporary huts (intended to last 10 years) were added in 1939. They are still there! The final change in its name occurred in 1951, when it became Barnet General.
